title: Identifying a Critical Nucleus for Ice Nucleation on Hydrophilic and Hydrophobic Surfaces
content: Water has long served as a critical topic in science and technology thanks to its ubiquitous existence in daily life. Water/solid interfaces are essential to an incredible range of everyday phenomena and technology developments, including wetting, corrosion, heterogeneous catalysis, environmental and atmospheric chemistry, biological science, and astrophysics [1-3]. Studies of surface-supported water clusters provide a means to obtain a rigorous molecular scale description of the initial stages of the above processes.
